lessonTitle: The Boundary as Ontological Act: From Distinction to Civilization

questions.question: According to the lesson, what three poles of reality are created by the act of abstraction?
questions.correct_answer: The Observed (phenomena on this side of the boundary), the Observer (the position of subjectivity), and the Non-observed or Nothing (the fundamental background from which the boundary is drawn).

questions.question: What are the two possible modes of relating to another Observer's boundary?
questions.correct_answer: Ignoring his boundary (which leads to violence and appropriation) or recognizing his boundary (which leads to cooperation and exchange).

questions.question: What is Level 6 of civilization according to the quantum levels described in the lesson?
questions.correct_answer: Civil Society, where the boundary becomes universal and virtual, recognized around any individual who accepts the rule of mutual non-aggression.

questions.question: What do the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse represent in this philosophical framework?
questions.correct_answer: They represent systemic forces unleashed when civilization destroys its own internal boundaries: White Horse (erasing local boundaries), Red Horse (war within society), Black Horse (violating boundaries of just distribution), and Pale Horse (destroying ecological equilibrium).

questions.question: According to the lesson, what is the starting point before the act of abstraction occurs?
questions.correct_answer: A pre-reflective state of undifferentiated Being - not chaos, but wholeness where there is neither subject nor object.
